segments.en: Linked Discourses 4
2. Rule
16. The Alms Bowls
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ upādāya bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
segments.en: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the five grasping aggregates.

segments.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
segments.en: And those mendicants were paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.
Then Māra thought,

segments.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ upādāya bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
segments.en: “This ascetic Gotama is educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the five grasping aggregates.

segments.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
segments.en: And the mendicants are paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.

segments.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ vicakkhukammāyā”ti.
segments.en: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā pattā abbhokāse nikkhittā honti.
segments.en: At that time several alms bowls were placed in the open air.

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā balībaddavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena te pattā tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of an ox and approached those bowls.

segments.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: One of the mendicants said to another,
“Mendicant, mendicant, that ox will break the bowls.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, the Buddha said to that mendicant,
“Mendicant, that’s no ox.

segments.pli: Māro eso pāpimā tumhākaṃ vicakkhukammāya āgato”ti.
segments.en: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:
“Sights, feeling, and perception,
consciousness and what is chosen:
‘I am not this’ and ‘this is not mine’;
that’s how to be free of desire them.
When you’re detached, secure,
all fetters transcended,
though Māra and his army chase everywhere
they never find you.”

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā … pe … tatthevantaradhāyīti.
segments.en: Then Māra … vanished right there.

suttaplex.blurb: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra takes the form of an ox and looks as if he will break their almsbowls.
